geninfo.para: The injector test is designed to detect problems with injection and combustion events. Performing a cylinder contribution test will analyze the individual contribution of each of the power cylinders. Its primary function is to detect a bad injector, although it will also detect problems that could affect the overall performance of the power cylinders (i.e.: valves, pushrods, pistons, rings, etc.). Further diagnostic testing (outside the scope of this TSI) may be necessary to resolve mechanical issues.

svcproc.title: KEY-ON ENGINE-RUNNING INJECTOR TEST

warning.para: To avoid engine damage, personal injury, possible death, be certain that the transmission is in neutral, parking brake is applied, and drive wheels are blocked prior to starting the engine.

svcproc.para: During this test the Electronic Control Module (ECM) will control fuel delivery and determine each cylinder's power contribution. If a cylinder is not performing satisfactorily, a Diagnostic Trouble Code (DTC) will be set.

figure.caption: Figure 1. Good Cylinder Contribution Test Recording

svcproc.para:
Some of the key areas to examine on the graphical display of the cylinder contribution test
are:

step1.para: When the test begins, the engine speed increases in increments up to 850 rpm.
The ECM increases fuel delivery to cylinder #1 (over-fuels) which causes engine speed to increase.
Fuel is reduced to remaining cylinders to maintain 850 rpm.
The ECM decreases fuel delivery to cylinder #1 (under-fuels) which causes engine speed to decrease.
Fuel is increased to the remaining cylinders to maintain 850 rpm.
At this point 2 key observations are noted:

item.para: The ECM compares fuel delivery of the remaining 5 cylinders during over-fuel condition.
The ECM compares fuel delivery of remaining 5 cylinders during under-fuel condition.

step1.para: If the difference is not what the ECM expects, a Diagnostic Trouble Code is set for the non-contributing cylinder. The procedure will repeat for the remaining cylinders until the test is complete.
The engine speed returns to low idle. The test is complete.

note.para: During the cylinder contribution test, the fuel rate graph represents fuel delivery to the remaining 5 cylinders.

svcproc.para: The cylinder contribution test begins with cylinder #1 (front cylinder) and is performed sequentially. The rpm fluctuation on engines with more than one severely scuffed injector can be enough to stop the cylinder contribution test.
Low or erratic fuel pressure can be enough to stop a Cylinder Contribution Test (CCT) or worse, give erroneous graphs and Diagnostic Trouble Codes.
A scuffed injector can be very difficult to diagnose. The best way to troubleshoot a scuffed injector is by using the EST and Master Diagnostics. Using Master Diagnostics KOER_CCT_I6.SSN:

item.para: Visualize - use the online graphs to compare one cylinder trace to another. Even the slightest scuffed injectors can display a significant change in pattern from a good injector.
Listen - watch the real-time graph and carefully listen to the sound characteristics of the engine.
Verify - when a Diagnostic Trouble Code is set, verify that there is a significant change in the graphic displays for that cylinder.

svcproc.title: TEST PROCEDURE - USING THE EST AND MASTER DIAGNOSTICS

note.para: All of the following screen views are based off of MD32 Version 2.3 default settings unless otherwise stated. You may have variations of views if you are using a different version of MD. If you have customized settings you may have a different view.

warning.para: To avoid personal injury, engine damage, possible death, be certain that the transmission is in neutral, parking brake is applied, and drive wheels are blocked prior to starting the engine.

step1.para: Start the engine and bring it up to its normal operating temperature above 160°F (71°C).

Start Master Diagnostics. Select the appropriate ECM application
. Selecting the wrong application will give you erroneous readings.

item.para: MD32 3BX - Three box engine controllers consisting of an Engine Control Module (ECM), Injector Driver Module (IDM), and a Vehicle Personality Module (VPM).
MD32 DLC- Diamond Logic Controller. This single box Engine Control Module (ECM) performs all of the functions that the three box can, however it is contained in one single unit.

step1.para: Connect the EST with the International® Truck interface cable to the 6 pin ATA connector located near the left side kick panel. For 9 pin ATA connectors, use the pigtail connector (6 pin to 9 pin) adapter tool ZTSE4467.

Select the Session drop-down menu bar and select Open to begin a session
.

Select the file KOER_CCT_I6.SSN (Key-On Engine-Running Cylinder Contribution Test)
from the Open Session File dialog window. The file name should now appear in the File Name box. Select Open.

When selecting a factory default session from International® Engine, Master Diagnostics automatically selects the correct COM port. Refer to the Master Diagnostics Software User's Manual for additional information.
Verify that the engine coolant temperature (ECT) is greater than 160°F (71°C).

It is essential to run the Key-On Engine-Running Standard Test in order to gain access to cylinder contribution testing. Select the Diagnostics drop-down menu bar, then select the
Key-On Engine-Running Standard Test
.

svcsubproc.para: The status bar will display the message DIAGNOSTICS RUNNING at the bottom of the screen .
If a diagnostic message appears, take note of the message, select OK and try again. If the message reappears, refer to the Diagnostic Tests section in the Master Diagnostics Software Users Manual.

step1.para:
When the standard test is complete, select the Diagnostics drop-down menu and select the Key-On Engine-Running Injector Test
.
If a diagnostic message appears, take note of the message, select OK and try again. If the message reappears, refer to the Diagnostic Tests section in the Master Diagnostics Software Users Manual.

While the test is running, the following parameters are observed in the Typical Graphical View
:

item.para: Engine Speed (RPM) (500-1000 rpm)
Engine Load (EL) (0-127.5%)
Fuel Rate (FR) (0-4 gal/hr)

svcsubproc.para: The status bar will display the message DIAGNOSTICS RUNNING at the bottom of the screen.

figure.caption: Figure 2. Typical Graphical View - Good (Consistent) Cylinder Contribution

step1.para:
The following graphic is an example of how a low fuel delivery injector appears during the test
.

note.para: Figure represents a graphical replay (SnapShot recording).
The graphical replay provided for interpretation was not severe enough to generate a Diagnostic Trouble Code.

figure.caption: Figure 3. Interpreting Graphical Data - Poor Cylinder Contribution

svcsubproc.para: When the over-fuel condition is compared to the under-fuel condition a significant difference is observed. This indicates that a particular cylinder is a strong contributor, or that the injector and power cylinder are functioning properly providing optimum output. CYL #1, 2, and 3 show evidence of well defined graphic traces, while CYL #4, 5, and 6 are viewed with suspicion. A weak contributing cylinder could be the result of a poorly functioning injector or a mechanical problem.

item.para: To maintain constant engine speed the ECM makes greater changes to the fuel rate than seen in weaker cylinders (cylinders 4-6).
There is a greater impact on Engine Load (EL).
To maintain constant engine speed the ECM makes minimal changes to the fuel rate than seen in stronger cylinders (cylinders 1-3).
There is a minimal impact on Engine Load (EL).

svcsubproc.para: The previously described procedure allows the technician to troubleshoot and repair the engine by replacing only the scuffed or defective injector(s). In the previous example the suspect injector(s) #6, #5, #4, (weak contributors) should be replaced.
If this fails to improve performance or significantly improve the graphical display, further mechanical diagnostic testing beyond the scope of this TSI is necessary.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, do not start the engine without priming the fuel system. Failure to do so will overload the injector tips. Priming the fuel system will be necessary. It has been found that "dry starts" after engine/fuel system maintenance contributes to injector tip failures. After engine service, when the fuel injection system is dry, cranking the engine to start without first priming the fuel system can result in an overload condition in injector tips. This overload occurs because there isn't any fuel present to cushion the needle valve as it lifts and seats. To avoid this condition, follow the procedure below after performing any maintenance that may allow air to enter the fuel system.

item.para: Disconnect the CMP (Camshaft Position Sensor).
Use the hand primer to fill the majority of the fuel system. Pump until hand primer is hard to depress.
Crank the engine three times for 15 seconds each. Reapply the hand primer after each crank cycle.
Once the hand primer is hard to depress (usually three crank and hand prime cycles), reconnect the CMP and start the engine.

svcsubproc.para: In cases where rust or corrosion is present within the injectors, some additional precautions are required.

item.para: Clean the entire fuel system of any water or other foreign contamination, including fuel tanks, fuel filter housings, strainers and fuel supply manifold.
After cleaning the fuel system, install and run existing injectors to purge the fuel system of any remaining contamination. Installation of new injector(s) can now be made.
It is recommended to replace all injectors that show signs of rust or corrosion.

note.para: Normally this is not considered a warrantable failure.

svcproc.title: SNAPSHOT RECORDING AND REPLAY OF A CYLINDER CONTRIBUTION TEST

svcsubproc.title: Snapshot Recording Of Cylinder Contribution Test
svcsubproc.para: The snapshot feature is an option that can be used to document the engine condition.

note.para: After the KOER_CCT_I6.SSN (session file) is open you may proceed with the following steps.

step1.para:
Select the Diagnostic drop-down menu and then select Key-On Engine-Running Standard Test
.

note.para: Do not arm the trigger when performing the KEY-ON ENGINE-RUNNING STANDARD TEST.

step1.para:
Select the SnapShot drop-down menu and select Arm Trigger
.

Verify the message Trigger Armed is active in the status bar
.

Select the Diagnostic drop-down menu and select the Key-On Engine-Running Injector Test
.

Verify that the Trigger Armed message changes to Recording as soon as the engine rpm is increased by the test
. You will also see the message Diagnostic Running message in the status bar.

When the test is complete the Diagnostic Running message disappears. To stop SnapShot recording select Stop from the setup menu
. When recording is complete, the Record message disappears.

note.para: To save multiple record files, the record file name must be changed for each recording. Failure to rename the record file will result in the file being overwritten. Refer to the Master Diagnostics Software Users Manual.

svcsubproc.title: Replay Of Cylinder Contribution Test
svcsubproc.para: The following procedure provides step by step instructions to replay a recorded session.

step1.para:
To review a SnapShot recording file, select Graphical Replay from the toolbar
.

Select file koer_cct_I6.rec from the pop-up window
.

note.para: If you saved multiple recording files, select the designated file.

step1.para:
Select Engine Speed and Fuel Rate from the pop-up menu to modify default attributes. To display, select Attributes
.

Modify Engine Speed Attributes. Enter 500 for minimum value and 1000 for maximum value. Select OK
.

Modify Fuel Rate Attributes. Enter 4 for maximum value
. Select OK.

To display a SnapShot recording file, select Display All then select OK. The recorded session will open
.
